If a method to seal the patient instead of healthcare worker per interaction with patient were invented and possible, that would certainly reduce the volume of waste generated from care work.
It should also reduce the cost both in terms of purchase of protective gear and disposal of contaminated gear.

description: What is needed is a modification of the sterile air tent with inserts for special plastic gloves so that patients could be treated without anyone touching them. It would be somewhat like the sterile cocoon prepared for David Vetter but easier because there is no need for absolute sterility of everything entering the tent. Tents could be placed in mobile clean rooms that would assist in keeping the caregivers free from infections. Both would be easily transportable and capacity could be location specific. Transporting the patient into the air tent would still require protective gear but once inside, the patient would not come into direct contact with anyone. Soiled bedding, bandages, etc. could be removed directly into sealed containers. Tents would be single use but by patient rather than by health care worker encounter. Mobile clean rooms could be re-used if patients were bedded into the tent before entering the clean room. A sample of the sterile tent and mobile clean room can be found at www.airflowequipments.com/sterile-air-tents.
summary: The key challenge is to prevent contact between the patient and the healthcare worker. Everything I've seen involves sealing the healthcare worker in protective gear that is single use. What if we seal the patient instead?
title: Seal the patient not the healthcare provider
